narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned quite a lot. It would be a bit lengthy to write everything down so I'll just try and summarize. Basically, the class is ab
Apart from decision theory, this course also increased my knowledge of microeconomics and even finance.
Economics about risk and uncertainty, adverse selection, and moral hazard.
I learned about where uncertainty and asymmetry of information occur in the market, how to model them, how they affect perfect equilibria, how to solve them and where the models break.
We learnt how to think about and implement economic theory on choice.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Professor Reiche is very good at her job. She was very very dedicated e.g. setting up additional office hours on a Friday night and a Saturday night. If that's not dedication then I don't know what is. Weaknesses: I can't think of any. The class should be kept as it is.

The Professor is amazing and the lectures very interesting. I really enjoyed the way that she constructed the lectures (topics, way of teaching etc). The problem sets were very challenging, but a perfect way of understanding the topics - so when its time to take exams, you are perfectly prepared. I do not think about any point that could be improved.

Soenje is definitely a strength of this class. She brings her lively teaching and passion to a very structured lecture, which leads to the class being all the greater. The slides are clear, the psets and exams are fair and help cement understanding. The weaknesses involve perhaps the leap in logic that sometimes happen from lectures to pset but Soenje does a good job of explaining what happens in the problem set in her office hours.

The course was well taught, especially given the remote format and difficult subject matter. Sometimes it is quite difficult to follow the math on slide presentations, but this is common of economics courses. It is also sometimes difficult to jump into the more challenging problem set questions from the baseline models from class. A possible solution is to have a course packet that has the key theories written down and explained with some more simple (ungraded?) questions to help familiarise us with the theory and warm us up for the problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The material was very good to read by your self. And during the lecture the professor always did some graphs with us, which was very helpful.

Lectures were entertaining and translated well to an online format. The use of an ipad and drawn diagrams during the class really helped. The recordings were useful to catch up on material one missed.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is an excellent senior seminar. If you enjoyed Intermediate Micro then you would really enjoy this class. The problem with intermediate micro is that it didn't feel too applicable to real life. In this class, you're going to learn so much about how individuals make choices under uncertainty and you will also go through several real-life studies. That being said, I would only recommend taking the class if Soenje Reiche is still teaching it because it's one of those classes that needs a good instructor otherwise things could be disastrous. Okay, maybe not disastrous but I do think that sometimes a class is only enjoyable if the instructor is great.

Yes, I would. It really helps you understand how problems are constructed in Microeconomics in general. Moreover, the  Professor is amazing (a very good lecturer) and helps students whenever they need.
Yes, but be aware that there is a decent amount of math involved.
Yes! Uncertainty and information concepts pervade many market relationships that are worth studying, and the class is well taught by a very considerate and caring professor.
Id recommend this course to a student who is interested in behavioural economics and who is strong in math.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I rewatched all the recorded lectures as revision
